pr_title: Change default hashing algorithm for FIPS 140

timeline.message:
Change default hashing algorithm for FIPS 140

Currently we disallow(via a startup check) any algorithm families
other than PBKDF2 when we expect Elasticsearch to run in a JVM in
FIPS 140 approved mode. However we do not change the default
hashing algorithm, which remains BCRYPT and that means that the
user needs to explicitly set the password hashing algorithm to
something compliant.
We know though, via the use of fips_mode.enabled, whether we
expect to run on a FIPS 140 JVM and we can change the default
hashing algorithm to one from the PBKDF family in that case.

This commit changes our default behavior and sets the password
hashing algorithm to PBKDF2 with a cost factor(no of iters)of 10000
when `fips_mode.enabled` is set to true.

timeline.bodyText: Why do we check both existence and actual value here? This is necessary when we want check something like "security is explicitly enabled, not implicilty enabled". Is this a similar situation here?
timeline.author: ywangd

replies.bodyText: Thanks, that is indeed unnecessary here. fips_mode is implicitly disabled and in any case we shouldn't differentiate between this having a default value or explicitly set to true.
replies.author: jkakavas

timeline.bodyText: Why is this check necessary? Is this our own requirement or imposed by JDK?
timeline.author: ywangd

replies.bodyText:
We use PBKDF2WithHMACSHA512 in  
  
    
      elasticsearch/x-pack/plugin/core/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/xpack/core/security/authc/support/Hasher.java
    
    
         Line 511
      in
      00b4d3d
    
    
    
    

        
          
           SecretKeyFactory secretKeyFactory = SecretKeyFactory.getInstance("PBKDF2withHMACSHA512"); 
        
    
  

 so we would like to be sure that the security provider that is used has this implementation up front ,rather than failing when we actually get to hash the first password. See #31234 (comment) also
replies.author: jkakavas
